div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Scakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor,(for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Important Announcement
Steam Ploughing, Cultivating, Levelling, and Grading.
div.p: Messrs. J. & H. McLaren, Manufacturers of Steam Ploughing Machinery, Midland Egine workds, leeds, now beg to announce their friends in Egypt, that Mr. Henry Mclaren, one of their principals will be in Egypt for the month of March 1906. He will be glad to make appointmentswith any interested parties to show them our steam plough tackle at work in Egypt, and will visit and inspect any lands on which it may be intended to work steam ploughs, and give most favourable prices for suitable Machinery.

He will also show them our new Patient Gassobesh, or levelling scoop, at work, which is the most imporved method of handling large quantities of sand or soil for levelling purposed which has yet to be put upon the market. Landed Propitore, Agriculturists, and Contractors are requested to communicate with Mr. McLaren at Shepeard's Hotel, Cairo after March 1st, 1906.

BIRTH. CHATAWAY.—On Monday, April 16th, to Mr. and Mr*. W. Perceval Chataway, a too. M ARRIAGE. BURTON-SMITH. — At 8t. Mark’s Church. Alexandria, on Wednesday, 18th April, by the Kev. Ganon Ward, M.A., John Hubbleday Barton, son of the late J. T. Burton, formerly of Fleming, Ramleh, to Mary Easter, second daughter of W. H. Smith, of Sidi Gaber.

THE INCREASE OF THE ARMY OF OCCUPATION. Tabah has borne its fruits and for the second time a Liberal Government has increased the British Army of Occupation in Egypt. This step will probably cause toms heart-burning in ‘'Nationalist’’ circles but the now situation crasted by the increase of the Turkish forces on the frontier of the Sinai and the occupation by them of Tabah and Gatah has rendered it neccesary for the British Government to show that it is on the ‘‘qoi ms. The diminution of the Army of Occupation in the autumn of 1904 was, in our opinion, perfectly justified by the political situation. British relations with France were extremely cordial, with Germany they were outwardly correct, and Count von Bulow had not yet spoken of “the abyse of war’’ nor had the Kaiser planned his visit to Tangier. The Ottoman Empire, as far as Egypt ns concerned, was considered a negligated quantity. All the world watched the Russo-Japanese straggle and the most startling excesses on the part of the Turks, Bulgarian!, Greeks, Albanians, and Vlachs could not persuade a single Power to interfere in the politics of the Near East. Then came a series of rather disturbing incidents. The Kaiser paid for famous visit to Tangier. At the same time Turkey and Gnat Britain quarrelled over Koweyt and the belief assiduously fostered by into* rested parties that Great Britain was supporting the Yemen rebels against the Saltan— a belief absolutely devoid of all foundation, by the way—caused a certain bitterness. Then came the Deleesed incident, the threats of war, %»d the challenge to the Anglo-French Agreement boldly thrown down by the German Empire. The Macedonian imbroglio followed. Once again the British Government and the Porte found themselves diplomatically opposed, and the Algeoiras Conference coincided strangely with the revival of Turkish activity on the eastern frontiers of Egypt. Under the circumstances the situation in Egypt could go fairly said to have altered materially. The Home Government has obviously realised this fact and the despatch oi fresh troops to Egypt will famish the British and the Egyptian Government* with a useful card in the rubber now being played with the 8ablime Porta. It is in no sense a threat to Turkey or to any other Power, it is simply * precautionary measure, rendered neccesary by recent events on the Eastern flank of the 8insi peninsula. There is no reason to suspect Turkey of aggressive designs on Egypt, but now that the Hedjss railway has brought Petreas and Bonthera Palestine under the strong hand of the Saltan and that Akaba may well be linked with 8tembonl in a few years' time it would be sheer folly on the part of the British Government not to recognise that the military situation in the Levant has been profoundly changed in the last twelve months.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Feast of the Prophet. The Mouled El Nebi will be held for one night only, at Abbasaieh on May 23. All Saints. Cairo. The Rev. Professor Sayce will preach at AU Saints’ Church, Cairo, on Sunday morning next. Service begins at 10.30 a m. Imports of Coal. The imports of coal from January 1 to April 19 amounted to 390,903 tons, as compared to 210,629 tons during the same period last year. The German Agency. Count von Bernsdorff, the newly appointed German Agent, ie expected to arrive in Cairo on the 25th inst. to take on his new duties as successor to Baron Rucker-Jenisoh. Quarantine in Turkey. A telegram from Constantinople states that vessels arriving in Turkish ports from Alexandria and Port Said are now subjected to a medical examination, disinfection, and “deratisation.” Homs International. A slight typographical error occurred in our i publication of the third list of donations to the above. Mme Constandi Sinadino’s donation appeared a, P.T. 97.5, whereas it should have been P.T. 975. Extension of Penny Postage. With effect from the 1st May next, the postage on letters for 8onthern Nigeria, Gambia, the Protectorate of British East Africa and Uganda, British Guiana, Turks Isles, and British Honduras, will be reduced and fixed at 5 milliemes for every 16 grammes or fraction thereof. St Andrew’s Church, The service in St. Andrew’s Church, Alexandria, on Sunday morning will be conducted by the Rev. Alf. A. Cooper, M.A, who will speak about the work of the British and Foreign Bible 3ooiety. The collection will be given on behalf on that society. Mex-les-Bains. Owing to the approaching demolition of the Casino and baths at Mex at the end of the J 1906 season in order to make room for the new passes, the Tramway Company has entered into negotiations with the Egyptian Government for a new site in the neighbourhood. Khedivial Opera House. According to a contemporary, the Khedivial Opera House will be left as it is until the year 1909, when it will be demolished and a new theatre built unless the Government sees fit to postpone both the demolition of the present opera house and the construction of its successor. Alexandria-Marseilles. Some English capitalists, among others Lord Armstrong, intend founding a line of turbine steamers of 14,000 tons between Marseilles and Alexandria. The voyage will take three days at a speed of twenty knots an hour. The passage rates will be 400 fa. 1st and 200 fra. 2nd class with 26 % reduction on return fares. New Tram Lines- 'The Alexandria Tramway Company is planning some new lines of tramways. One of the chief of these will pass by the new quays and unite the populous native quarters of Abon-el Abbas and Ras-el-Tin with the centre of the city, and terminate in the other direction at Nouzha Gardens on the Mahmondieh Canal. A False Rumour. "A1 Abram.” which published the news of the divorce of Princess Fatimeh Hanem, second wife of H.H. Prince Kamel Pacha Fadel and widow of the late Menshawi Pacha, now contradicts the news, explaining that the false statement was communicated to it by parties who evidently had a motive in making it public. div.head: THE DANGER PAST.
'FRISCO'S WATER SUPPLY PARTIALLY RESTORED.
div.p: LondoN, Saturday. According to the latest cables from New York the Mayor of San Francisco has notified those remaining in the city that with the partial restoration of the water supply the danger has passed. Apropos of the terrible earthquake at San Francisco last Wednesday it is significant that last Saturday’s London newspapers contain a telegram from Seattle stating that Mount Rainier had suddenly developed volcanic activity. For three days previously it had been emitting ashes and flame which could be seen fifty miles away. A Berlin telegram dated the 12th inst. says : — At four o’clock this morning the seismograph at Gottingen registered new earthquakes in distant regions, hat of an extraordinary intensity. According to the calculations of the seismographic experts the shocks had their origin in southern Italy. If this supposition is confirmed, it would seem to support the belief that the seat of the volcanic upheaval originated at a considerable depth, and that other disasters may be expected.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: Thursday’s bulletin reported five new cases at Samalont, six deaths outside hospital and two in hospital at the same place and four deaths in hospital at Deshna. Yesterday were reported two new oases, three deaths in hospital, and one outside hospital at Deshna and a death outside hospital at Samalont Twelve oases remain under treatment.

div.head: FREEMASONRY IN EGYPT
div.p: A Masonic correspondent writes :— In reference to discussions in Egypt about the regular hodies, the Supreme Council for the Northern Masonic Jurisdiction of the United States of America in its last year book of 1905 giving a report of the 93rd annual meeting held at Indianapolis, Indiana, says about Egypt- “Papers have been received from a body styling itself the Supreme Council for Egypt, with Grand Orient at Cairo. While this is not the Supreme Council with which we were in correspondence some yean ago, it is probably the successor of the former, which seems to have passed out of existence. “That Council, according to my recollection, was located at Alexandria. The status of this Supreme Council should also be investigated in connection with that of others to which I have referred, that, if found to be regular, we may enter into correspondence with it and exchange representatives. EGYPTIAN OPTIONS. In reference to the recent sensational discovery of gold on the concession controlled by the Egyptian Options and the London, Johannesburg and Cairo Trustees, it is worth pointing out that the capital of Options is £50,000 while the Cairo Trustees has only £10,000. On the basis of the recent rise in Options the ordinary shares of the Cairo Trustees are worth £6 each, and the Deferred between £80 and £l00. Two or three financial groups are trying to buy out the interest of the Cairo Trustees as they consider that this is one of the most important mining discoveries since the finding of the celebrated Golden Mile in Australia. The Egyptian Option group are about to spend £50.0f 0 to open np this sensational find, which it is expected will put Egypt in the front rank of gold producing countries.

div.head: THE LEWA'S BALLON D'ESSAI
TURKEY AND THE SINAI
NO KNOWLEDGE OF ALLEGED DEMANDS
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service ) London, Saturday. The “Daily Telegraph’s” Correspondent at Constantinople says that neither the Porte nor the British Embassy has any knowledge of the absurd demands which Turkey is reported to have made in regard to the Sinai peninsula. The reports are supposed to be mere "ballons d’essai” published by the Egyptian paper “El Lewa.” “Negotiations are proceeding”—both sides marking time till the return to Cairo of H.H. the Khedive from Alexandria, when it is hoped that Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha will pat forward fresh proposals. SULTAN’S ILLNESS. REPORT DBNIKD. London, April 20. The Turkish Embassy absolutely denies the reports of the serious illness of the Sultan. (Renter) INCREASE OP BRITISH GARRISON. With regard to the increase of the British Garrison, reported by Reuter yesterday, we learn that a regiment of cavalry and two batteries of Field Artillery are to embark for Egypt at once, and the half-battalion of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, which went to Crete last month, will return to Cairo. With regard to infantry, there will be a further increase later on if matters at Akaba should warrant any such increase. Our native contemporary “A1 Ahram” is of opinion that the increase of the Army of Occupation is due to an exaggerated idea of the importance of the frontier dispute. It remarks that the British flag flying over the British Agency is a sufficient guarantee for the maintenance of public order in Egypt, and recommends Egyptians to content themselves by demanding of the British Government a continuance of the policy of preserving public order and guaranteeing justice and individual security, which has aided Egypt to reach that pitch of ^prosperity which the country now enjoys. H.M.S. PERSEUS. Our London Military and Naval Correspondent writes:— The cruiser Thetis is about to be commissioned to take out a relief crew to Port Said for the cruiser Persons, which is to be recommissioned for another spell of service on the East Indies Station. The Thetis will return home with the paid-off crew of the Persons. The Hyacinth, ex-flagship of the But Indies Squadron, just arrived home from Bombay, will be commissioned with a nucleus crew for service in the Devonport Reserve. SIR CLINTON DAWKINS’ ESTATE. Probate has been granted of the will of the, late Sir Clinton Edward Dawkins, K.C.B., of Polesdon Lacey, Surrey. whose estate is sworn at £118,404 gross and £72 869 net. The executors are the widow, Lord Milner, and Mr. Cyril Barle Johnston, Lady Dawkins’ uncle. After giving certain legacies, and directing a trust fund to be set aside for the benefit of his widow and daughter, all the residue of the estate is given to Lady Dawkins absolutely. LORD CROMER AND THE MILITIA EXPERIMENT. The “Spectator” says We have received from Lord Cromer a subscription of £2 for our Militia Experiment The fact that one whom we may describe without the least fear of being accused of exaggeration as among the greatest of living Englishmen is watching our experiment with interest and approval will, we feel sore, be a subject for sincere congratulation among all Lord Cromer’s co-subscribers. Again, we are sore that the men of the Spectator Company still feel proud of encouragement from each a source, for they are fully alive to the fact that they engaged in an experiment of great public importance, and are determined to do their best to render it a success and an example. Though Lord Cromer has won the great position which he occupies in the Empire and in the hearts of his fellow- countrymen by his work as a civil governor, it must never be forgotten that he began his official life as an army reformer. As a young man he was closely associated with the great reforms introduced into our army by Mr. Cardwell, under whom he acted in the capacity of private secretary. Ever since, Lord Cromer has remained an army reformer, and he has always watch ad any schemes for the sound development of our military forces with a lively personal interest.

div.head: THE FLOATING DOCK
THE CAPTAIN INTERVIEWED
PREPARATIONS FOR ENTERING CANAL
div.p: (From our Correspondent). Port Said, Friday. I am now in a position to send farther particulars regarding the Dewey and her consorts’ voyage, having been enabled to interview the captain to-day. It appears that the Dewey, after a "false start,” finally left the States on the 29th December last, coupled np all her huge hawsers and towing cables, of which there were over two miles, and from the coast line for some 500 miles enjoyed fair weather. After several repeated trials to tow in a freshening breeze it was found advisable to let go the lines until the weather moderated, when the ships got hold of the dock again and proceeded. This operation, seeing the futility of trying to tow with safety in the slightest of bad weather, was gone through several times, much, \ no doubt, to the anxiety and danger of all concerned, for to manipulate huge hawsers of 22 inch circumference and to handle cables of 6 inch diameter is by no means easy. The task set the crew of the Dewey was no light one, and those who volunteered for such arduous and hazardous work in the face of so many known and unknown dangers are men of whom the American or any other nation may be proud. The dosk is 500 feet long and 184 feet wide, and has a height of 61 feet, which is supported on a pontoon 18 feet deep. She has a naval crew of 37 who lodge anywhere at all about the pillars in the very acme of discomfort. Signalmen, wireless operators, and electricians seem to have been exceptionally busy, for of course constant communication had to be kept np with the tags, three large 5,000-ton ships. The Dewey arrived at Las Palmas after a voyage of 56 days, and lay there for a few days undergoing some slight repairs rendered necessary by the numberless occasions on which the dock was struck by heavy seas. From Las Palmas she came right on here, the three tags in tandem, coupled together with 5-in. chain and immense hawsers, and reached Port Said after only 32 days at sea in spite of the fact that on several occasions they were obliged to stop towing and let the dock go, with the approach of bad weather. \ l The three ships and the tugboat are now lying on the east side of the harbour, and they, together with the dock, ate to remain here about 10 days getting ready for the next long stay at sea and to give the Suez Canal Co. time enough to lift those buoys in the canal which would undoubtedly much interfere with her voyage through. The deep channel in the Canal is buoyed with buoys 46 metres apart, so it will be readily understood, seeing that buoys are placed at every font-tenths of a mile, what a quantity of preparation has to be made before the Dewey can be allowed to enter. The Canal tags will do the actual towing and the towing ships will only couple on after the dock has left the Canal at the Seez end. THE SUCRBRIES. We understand that the Parquet is about to take proceedings against the Hon. A. J. Davey, M. Nan, and M. Arbib, directors of the company, on the ground of fraudulent bankruptcy. Messrs. Leronx, Dorizon, Ternynok are not being proceeded against for the present by the Mixed Parqaet, which does not wish to hamper in any way the action of the French Court, before which the three directors named have been brought on a serious charge, as reported by ns a few days ago. ‘HOW TO DEFY THE TURK.’’ Mach criticism has been devoted lately to a report presented at Washington by Mr. Marcus Braun, who was recently appointed, immigrant inspector. Speaking of immigration from Turkey, Asia Minor, and Syria, Mr. Braun says the Armenians have invented a scheme whereby they can stay in Turkey and at the same time defy Turkish laws. This consists of a large number of Armenians emigrating to the United States, and as soon as they have earned sufficient money for their need they return supplied with American citizenship papers, and continually conspire against the Turkish Government under the protection of American citizenship. The same is true in Syria and Palestine, he says, and he quotes the Governor of Mount Lebanon as saying: “If this constant travel from Syria to and from the United States does not cease soon, the United States had better annex the province of Lebanon, as at present there are more American citizens there than Turkish subjects.” In Jerusalem alone Mr. Brann found more than 1,000 "American citizens,’’ and ho declares that 99 per cent. of them speak not a ' word of English, and most of them do not know the street of the city in which they claim to have resided while in the United States.

div.head: DUKE OF ABRUZZI
IMPORTANT EXPEDITION
ARRIVAL AT PORT SAID
div.p: To-day the Duke of the Abruzzi’s expedition to the Mountains of the Moon is due to arrive at Port Said en route to its destination, whence it still return to Europe by way of the Nile valley. No previous expedition has been organised on snob an elaborate scale as that which the Duke of the Abruzzi is preparing to lead to the assault of the mysterious African range. No fewer than a dozen Europeans are engaged in the enterprise. In addition to the Duke of the Abruzzi the expedition includes Captain Cagni, Dr. Cavalli, Lieutenant Winspeare, Dr. Ronesti, and Signor Vittorio Sella, as well as two Alpine guides, two porters, an assistant photographer, and a cook. With such a company at his back the Duke should be able to make a bold bid for success and add another leaf to his laurels is an explorer. In view of the nature of his task it is opportune to recall that in 1897 he led the first expedition that succeeded in reaching the summit of Mount St. Elias, the great mountain of Alaska towering to a height of upwards of 18,000ft. Captain Cagni, of course, was the commander of the Stella Polare on the Duke of the Abruzzi’s Arctic expedition in 1899-1900, and it was he who led the sledging party that readied latitude 86deg. 83min. N., the most northerly latitude yet attained, though only a few miles beyond Dr. Nansen’s farthest Signor Vittorio Sella, the photographer of the expedition, has in particular done admirable work among the Canoasna, so that with the two Alpine guides there will be no lack of mountaineering experience among the members of the party. Dr. Ronesti is a geologist and the expedition will, it is hoped, result in important additions to our knowledge of the geological structure and other scientific features of Rawenzori.

div.head: HOTEL DU NIL
CAIRO'S OLDEST HOTEL FINALLY CLOSED.
div.p: This week has seen the last of this well- known hostelry, as snob. Founded in 1836 aa a small hotel with some 40 beds by Mme Below, a French lady, it was for many years the only hotel in Cairo. About the year 1856 it passed into the hands of Mr. Edward Friedmann, who made many additions to it. He was succeeded in his proprietorship by Mr. Battigelli, an Italian architect and son- in-law of Mr. Friedmann, and now it has passed into the hands of one of the largest i Egyptian land companies. Property and land in the Mousky quarter, owing to the increasing demand for business accommodation there, has now reached a price at which it is no longer possible to carry on a hotel business, being worth from £40 to £50 per square metre. The old gardens and present rite of the Hotel do Nil, amounting to a whole faddan in extent, have long been famous, and even before the hotel was first founded it was knows throughout Egypt as the headquarters of the great Napoleon. It was hero that he took np lis residence in 1802, and the bouse which he then occupied was only demolished some 15 years ago to make room for modern improvements and hotel requirements. “Sio transit gloria mundi.” Daring the seventy yean in which the Hotel da Nil has existed it has housed many celebrities. Amongst others Emin Pacha and Giezler Pacha, the friend of Gordon, were to be found there. Many Royalties have accepted its hospitality. Prince Rudolph, the late Crown Prince of Austria, was a constant visitor, as also were the Archduchess Stephanie, Prince Rupert of Bavaria, the King of Saxony, Prince Bismarck Bohlen.ani many others have resided there. By order of the present proprietors the whole of the valuable contents of the hotel still be sold by auction without reserve by Mr. de la Tore* the well-known auctioneer. The sale will commence at 9 o’clock on Monday, the 30th inst, and will be continued daily every afternoon at 8 o’clock. The hotel and its contents will be on view to intending purchasers during the three previous days, and we strongly recommend thorn requiring furniture, linen, silverplated goods, cooking utensils, etc., not to lose this opportunity, for there will undoubtedly be many good bargains going. The name and title of the Hotel da Nil have been acquired by Mr. Charles Bauer, of the Bristol and National Hotels. THE CONGO-N1LB ROUTE. The Antwerp correspondent of a London contemporarily is responsible for the following story : Some months ago the Congo Free State shipped from Antwerp, vii the Nile, several automobiles. At Alexandria the British authorities refused to allow the vehicles to continue vii the Nil* and they were consequently returned to Antwerp. To-day the same automobiles were reshipped for the Congo, via Alexandria and the Nile.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: We are pleased to learn that Mr. F. G Freeman, H.B.M.’s Vice-Consul at Alexandria, has been promoted Consul and appointed to the Vilayets of Trebizond and Siva*, with residence at Trebizond. Rustovitz Bey, who has received a personal invitation from the Crown Prince of Greece to witness the Olympic Games, has left for Athens. Rev. F. B. N. Norman-Lee, M. A., C. F. has been granted leave of absence to May 8, and is leaving for Athens. The many friends of Col. A T. Sloggett, C. M. G., in Egypt will be interested to learn that the P. M. 0., London District, has proceeded to Lisbon to attend the International Congress of Medicine as English delegate. No better officer in the Royal Army Medical Corps could have been selected, for he possesses all the requisites for presenting to the foreigners who will be present the best that our Army Medical Service can show. The Royal Geographical Society has awarded the Cuthbert Peek Grant to Major Austin, C. M. G., D. S. 0., R. K, for the survey work he has carried out in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and British East Africa. We are pleased to hear that Mr. Vita Castro has been appointed a director of Messrs. Allen. Alderson and Co., limited. We are sore that his numerous friends will be glad to learn that he has joined the board of the firm with whom he has been connected for so many yean. The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh: Mr.Th. Hamilton, Miss Hamilton, Glasgow; Mr. and Mrs. R. H. Shelmerdine and suite, Leeds; Mr. EL EL Kent, London; Mr. and Mme G. Saint Plancat,Cairo; Mr. and Mrs. W. L Smith, England ; Mr. and Mrs. B. Scott, Mr. and Mn. David, Cairo; Mr. and Mrs. James Watson, Alexandria; Mr. A S. White, Elinburgh; the Misses Delanoy, Cairo; Mr. and Mrs. B. Sounder* Liverpool; Mr. and Mn. John Boss, Alexandria ; Mr. K Peer, Mr. F. Walter, London.

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS
A DAY OF HORROR
'FRISCO STILL ON FIRE
300,000 PEOPLE HOMELESS
INDESCRIBABLE CONFUSION AND DISTRESS
div.p: New York, April 20. According to some estimâtes 5,000 persons have perished at San Francisco but up to now it has not been possible to verify these figures. Yesterday was a day of horror ; foar distinct zones of fire were threatening to drive into the sea 20.0C0 refugees huddled together in Golden Gâte Park : the ferries were overcrowded by half-crazed refugees who assert that hundreds perished in the flames, including many prisoners in the hall of the Court of Justice. It is reported that Terminal Island and other seaside resorts hâve been destroyed by a tidal wave. {Reuter) New York, April 20. Three fires were still burning fiercly in San Francisco yesterday night. Whole blocks of buildings hâve been blown up by dynamite to arrest the flames, but to no purpose. Ail the millionaire’s houses hâve been destroyed. The confusion and distress amidst hunger and raging thirst are indescribable. Every city in the United States is vying in the despathc of relief. Mr. Rockefeller and other millionaires are contributing huge sums. Up to the present it is roughy estimated that two-thirds of the city have been destroyed: the fire is still spreadin gin two directions but less furiously: it is now hoped to save a qurter of the city There are three hundred thousand people homeless, hungry and thirsty: the police have seized all the food and are distributing it sparingly. General Funston telegraphs that only the most energetic outside efforts can prevent frightful suffering. The government have seen directed thatthe purchase of stores of food be made at the nearest centres, and the Secretary of Commerce has been sent to investigate the best methods for further relief. The extraordinary mingling of earthquake and fire causing great uncertainty in insurance circles: it is understood that one-third of the losses will fall on British offices.

div.head: THE NATAL TROUBLES
div.p: Durban, April 20. Dinizulu, son of Cetewayo, has offered to prove his loyalty by capture Bambaata. The authorities, however, are not altering their plans for putting a total 7,000 men into the field.

div.head: INTERNATION MEDICAL CONGRESS
div.p: Lisbon, April 20. King Carlos opened the INternational Medical Congress here, two thousand representatives of 30 countries attending.

div.head: FRENCH STRIKES
div.p: PARIS, April 20.There are 8,000 troops now at Lens. The day passed quietly but for few slight disturbances. The postal strike has collapsed. Collisions between strikers and troopers took placein Douai, Lens, Valenciennes, and LIlle distritcs to-day. M. Clemenceau is touring in the region and endeavouring to mediate between the miner and owners. M. Etienne has arrived at Lens and decorated the injured troops: he attended the funeral of the lieutenant who was killed. LENS April 20. MM. Clemenceau and Etienne ware the chief mourners at the funeral of the lieutenant who died as a reslult of his wounds. M. Etienne handed nine decorations to wounded officers. Several soldiers were injured with stones in a collision with the strikers.

div.head: KAISER AND VESUVIUS
div.p: BERLIN, April 20. The Emporer William has contributed 500 to the Vesuvius relief fund started in Germany.

div.head: NAVAL GUNNERY ACCIDENT
div.p: PARIS, April 20. Three were killed and twenty-two injured by a gunnery accident on a French gunnery instruction ship at Toulon. Three sailors were killed and 17 injured in a gunner accident on board the Couronne.

div.head: RACING
div.p: LONGDON, April 20. Craven Stakes: 1. His eminence; 2. Bridge of Canny; 3. Venetian.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS
div.p: The report of th Egyptian Markets, Ltd. for 1905, to be presented at the meeting on the 30th instant, states that the Government decree closing all markets to horned cattle was withdrawn on 20th November, 1905, from which date the markets were reopened after having been, in consequence of the cattle plague, partially closed since June, 1903 and entired so since February, 1904. Unfortunately, a local outbreak of the plague has again necessitated the closing some of the markets in the Beni Souef and Fayoum Provinces, but it is thought that the thorough measures taken by the Government Sanitary Department will effectually prevent any srious deleopement. The total gross receipts from all sources are 26,537 of which 15,951 was derived from cattle markets, 9,387 from general markets, 597 from abattoirs and 601 from sundry other sources. In order that efficient supervision should be given to those departments of the markets which were not closed it was found necessary to maintain the existing establishment in Egpty. The cost of working the markets has been 17,908, a slight increase on the previous year from all sources. After meeting administration and working expenses amounts to 8,630, which, with the balance brought toward from 1903, makes a total of 17,724 to be dealt with. After payment of the annual premiums for the amortisation of the share and debenture interest 4,274 a balance of 9,129 remains available for distribution. In view of the reopening of all the markets and the resultant satisfactory returns and prospects, an interim dicident of 5 percent was paid December, 1905, on the ordinary shares. It is proposed to still further increase the number in the future. Every possible assisstance has been and is being given to the Government officials in their efforts to effectively and entively stamp out the cattle disease. It is anticipated that for the present, notwithstanding the stricted precaution, small local outbreaks may recur at increasing intervals from time to time, but under the existing stringent measures it is thought the disease will not spread to any extent. The directors wish to draw the proprietors' attention to the fact that notwithstanding the closing of the markets careful and economical administration has enabled the company to carry forward a small credit balance on the year's trading after paying debenture interest and sinking ufnd premium on the share and debenture capital. The directors have with deep regre to report the death f Mr. Wilbeforce Bryant. It is not for the present proposed to fill the vacant seat on the Board.

div.p: Les articles qni ont pam ici et aillenre ao jri»t dn Mabmoudirh et de la creation d’nte convelle brarehe de e? oanal ont naturellement pre'.vope {’opinion pobFque. II taut erperer i! o;t element attire l'attention des poo- voirs publics et cello de nos edilee. Si, com me on le soatient, on doit exeoutor des traranx important* sur le Mahmondieh, il est Evident Ha’tl y faadra les conconrs de toot le monde et l sppai re’l et serienx de la Commission Municipals d’Alfrardrie ec partionlier. II seuable qa’il soit temps ponr les *los de la Cite de e pfeoccnper des graves prtb’bmea qai cai? eat da d*veloppement luficce de la villa et dont la elution importe loaoc^up pins qae les pins petiteset me qaines qaerelles qoi, trap soavent, o*cnpent les stances de la l'e’.igation etde la Ctmmission. Nous ne pfetendona pas eoatecir d’satre psrtjqae ce soit k la 'villa de pourvoir k l’ex*- catioo de travanx dont l’E.ypte entfere doit tirer profit, msis none avons la pretention d'etre daDS la v*rit* en effirmant qne l'initia- tive de tons les prrjets qni concerner.t Alex- andrie devrait appartenir aox Conseillers Mnnicipaox. La villa nest pas senlement constitute par la Boorse, la me Chtrif et la roe Rosette ; il ne s'agit pas nniqnement d’assnrer l’tclairage, le baUysge et 1’arrosage des qnartiera riches, il fiat encore qae l’on se prtoccape de oe qne sera l’Alexandrie de demaia lorsque, par le progrfesde son commerce exttrieor, elledon- blera one fois enoore son importation tont en aogmentant, gram k l'extension de la cnltnre da cot-on, la qnautit* de see exportations. A-t-on sing* dans qnel *tat se tronve an- jonrd’hni le qaartier de Minet-el-Bassal ? Sait-on qne les essarenre ont retoi* d'assomer les risque* d'icoet.d e si l’on continnait k enoom- brer las roes dee balles de ooton 1 Les roes sont-ellee faitee ponr permettre arx pittons et anx vthicnles de ton tee sortee de oircnler dans les meillenres conditions de repidit* ! Il soffit d’aller iaire nn tonr k Minet-el-Bassal ponr se rend re oompte qae lee roes ne sont pas faites ponr lee gens, mais bien ponr les mar- chandises; an tan t de rnes antant de maga- sins. Si avec le port, tel quil eset actuellement, il est deja impossible de circuler, que sera-cedonc lorsque les travaux en cours d'execution ou a executer dans un avenir prochain seront complemenent termines. Mais combien plus grand encore sera l'embarras lorsque, au developpement de l'importantation, correspondront des arrivages plus nombreauz de coton et de graines? Croit-on que la recolite egypienne va rester tonjours stationaire 1 personne ne le soutiendra et les derniers rapports du Conseilier Financier temoignent, une fois encore, de la volonte tres ferme et tres reflechie du gouvernement de tout faire peur ameliorer la culture du coton tout en liviant auz fellahs, grace a des irrigations de mieux en mieux concues et de plus en plus perfectionnees, des surfaces tonjours plus etendues.Que deviendra le commmerce alexandrin lorsque la double eventualite que nous indiquons se sera produite et elle se produira tatalement si on ny prend garde. Comment les conseillers municipaux se desinteresseraient-ils de cetter question? Nous avons deja parle des moyens e parer aux difficultes qui vont en saggravant tous les jours et la creattion dun nouveau canal actual. Or, comme on l'a fait remarquer justement, un pareil projet couterait des sommes considerables sansamener la degagement dun quartier qui est deja hours d'etat de suffire aux besoins actuels du commerce. Nous ne pensons pas non plus que l'on doive combler le canal actuel pour le remplacer par un autre; le project etudie par l'administration du port, prevoit, au contrair, que le canal- actuel continuera a fonctionner, mais dans certaines conditions de telle facon qu aucun interest ne soit lese, main il previot pour une somme relativement minime quand on songe aux resultates de l'enterprise, le crensement d'une nouvelle voie naviable parcourant des terrains inoccupes ou l'on pourrait facilement creer une ville nouvelle. Le resultat serait merveilleux, tout le monde en conviendra comme nous, car ce serait surtout pour le commerce. Liberte complete de debarquer et dembarquer les marchandises; ce serait l'affranchisement de toutes les entraves, de toutes les vaxations. Le projet est il pratiquement executable? Les ingenineurs competents qui l'ont etudie l'affirment. Il nous faut entrer a ce suject dans quelques detials.

div.head: THE ABOUKIR COMPANY
div.p: The report of the directors submitte to the shareholders at the 19th ordinary meeting of the company, held in London yesterday, states it is with deep regret they have to record the great loss the company has sustained by the death in October late of the late chairman, Mr. Samuel G. Sheppard, who was one of the original founders of the company. To his conrage and support in all period of difficulty the shareholders are largely indebted for the properity the company at present enjoys. The directors also regret to have to report the resignation of Mr. Leonard B. Schlesinger, who had been a director of the ocmpany from within a few months of its formation. Early in the past year Mr. Marthur Ballance joined the board and more recently Mr. Sheppard and Mr. Pelly were appointed to fill the two vacant seats. The total sales of land, including thos of pervious years are as follows. During the past year 699 feddans were sold on deferred payments, extending over five to ten years, for 46,765. COnsiderably more than one-half of this area, ahving been reclaimed, realized an average of about 76 per feddan, and the remiander, only recently casualized, about 15. For cash about 406 feddans of uncanalized land were sold for 12,687 but the contract for this sale waas made in 1904 when prices were not so high as during the past year. The above sales show a steady increase in prices, and a good deal more land could have been sold had the company been willing to break into the compact division of Wastani and Bahari. Mandara division (4,170 feddans.) - No land was taken in hand for canalization in this division during the year, but 800 feddans, partly reclaimed, were further advacned, of which the gerater part should let at good rates next November. About 1,000 feddans will be canalized this year and a new staff house, with offices, magazines &c, built. BAHARI DIVISION (3,270) feddans. The greater part of the land in this division has been in hand for a considerable period, but as reported last year, a large amount of levelling has had to be done. The progress made during they year has, however, been satisfactory and it is now proposed to canalize the remianing 600 feddans.Buildings for workmen and tenants were built of brick made on the spot, this being the first time bricks have been successfully burned by the company. The cost compares favourable with stone, and future buildings will be largely constructed of brick. A large area of this division should be ready for letting at the end of the year. Good progress has been made in reclaiming the 1,577 feddans purchased in conjunction with two otehr companies in the province of Gharbieh, of which 137 feddnas have been let for the first year at an average rent of 410 per feddan. The initial difficulties and delay in taking over a new property having been overcome, rapid progress should now be made in reclaiming the land. From the accounts presented the profit and losst accounts. It is proposed to pay dividends for the past year of 7 percent. On both the ordinary and deferred shares, which will amount to 11,769 and leaving 21,699 to be carried forward.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
RAS-EL-TIN SCHOOL.
div.p: GYMNASTIC DISPLAY. On thursday afternoon ras-el-tin school grounds were quite filled by an enthusiastic crowd of spectators gathered to watch young Egypt in the role of athlete. All classes of the Alexandira community, native and European, were present. The first item on the proframme was a football match in which the opposing teams played clean, clever football. The programme of gymnastics included exercises with dumb bells, the parallel bars, and the "horse." The dumb-bell display was probably the best of an excellent show: the "time" was especially good. Unfortunately, the drill instructor, Ibrahim Effendi, had a very severe fall while leading his pupils on the parallel bars. He was unconcious for some time, but we are glad to hear he is now making satisfactory progress. Inspector Brockway, who was present, then took up the instructor's duties, and brought a most interesting afternoon's work to a satisfactory conclusion. The tug-of-war was a stiff fight; one or two of the pullers must have turned the scale at fourteen stone, we should imagine. Ismail Bey Hassanein, the headmster, and his staff did their very best to look after the comfort of the guests, and the tea-tent was well patronized. The prizes, which were many and valuable, were presented to the winners by H.E. Ibady Pachs, Governor of Alexandira, assisted by Admiral Sir Bloomfield and other English visitors. The prize for the best all-round gymnast was awkarded to Halim Fahmy; a good specimen of the wiry young Egyptian. The school is to be hearily congratulated on a display which would have compared favourably with the Public School exhibition at Aldershot.

div.head: Rear-Admiral Hichborn Praises Pe-ru-na.
div.p: ADMIRAL'S WORDS CARRY WEIGHT. Rear-admiral Hichborn is one of the best known admirals of our navy. His statement concerning Peruna will have much weight as it goes out into the world. What he says is echoed by many other naval officers of high standing.

WHAT THE ADMIRAL SAYS. Phillip Hichborn, Rear-Admiral United States Navy, writes from Washington D.C. as follows: "After the use of Peruns for a short period, I can now cheerfully recommend your valuable remedy to any one who is in need of an invigorating tonic."- Phillip Hichborn.

AN EVERPRESENT FOE. The solder and the sailor are especially subject to catarrh in some form or phase. Exposed as htey are to constant changes, subject as they are to various vicissitudes and all kinds of climate, wet and dry night and day, they find catarrh to be their most insidious and everpresent foe. In the barracks and on the field, Peruna is equally efficacious. Taken in time, it will absolutely prevent catching cold.

PE-RU-NA AN ABSOLUTE SPECIFIC. After a cold has become established, Peruna will break it up quicker than any otehr remedy known to mn. Even after a cold has been settled in some organ of the pody Peruna can be relled upon to promptly dispel it. Peruna will cure catarrh, whether acute or chronicm but a few doses taken in the first stages of the disease will be more effective tahn when the diease has become chronic. If you suffer from catarrh in any form, do not neglect it. Take Peruna at once. Delays in such matters are dangerous.
RECOMMENDS PE-RU-NA. "I am convinced of Peruna's curative qualities and I unhesitatingly recommend it to all persons suffering from catarrh."- Commodore Somerville Nicholson.

FROM HIS OWN EXPERIENCE. "The use of your Preuna as a remedy and cure for catarrh by many of my friedns who have been benefited by the same, as well as my own experience as to its efficiency and good tonic properities, causes me to recommend it to all persons."- Ex-Liet. U.S. Navy James M. Morgan.

PE-RU-NA CURES THROAT CATARRH. "I can cheerfully recommend your remedy, Peruna, to my friends and otehr sufferers as one of the best remedies I have ever treid for catarrhal troubles of the throat and kindred disesaes. I also consider Peruna a grand tonic."- Admiral James A. Greer.
FOR COUGHS AND COLDS. "I have used your Peruna with satisfaction and can cheerfully recommend the remedy as an effective remedy for coughs and colds."- Rear-Admiral J.A. Howell.

For special directions everyone should read "The ills of Life" a copy of whichsurrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists. A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up,” and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
